title: The Ultimate Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy
author: Douglas Adams

highlights.representative_text: It takes eight minutes to journey from the star Sol to the place where the Earth used to be, and four years more to arrive at Sol's nearest stellar neighbor, Alpha Proxima.
highlights.selected_text: It takes eight minutes to journey from the star Sol to the place where the Earth used to be, and four years more to arrive at Sol's nearest stellar neighbor, Alpha Proxima.

highlights.representative_text: One of the major difficulties Trillian experienced in her relationship with Zaphod was learning to distinguish between him pretending to be stupid just to get people off their guard, pretending to be stupid because he couldn't be bothered to think and wanted someone else to do it for him, pretending to be outrageously stupid to hide the fact that he actually didn't understand what was going on, and really being genuinely stupid.
highlights.selected_text: learning to distinguish between him pretending to be stupid just to get people off their guard, pretending to be stupid because he couldn't be bothered to think and wanted someone else to do it for him

underlines.representative_text: He woke up blearily, got up, wandered blearily round his room, opened a window, saw a bulldozer, found his slippers, and stomped off to the bathroom to wash.
“I’m trying to, baby, I’m trying to,” is what Ford invariably replied on these occasions.
The Earth moved slowly in its diurnal course.
he asked plaintively.
He looked into the sky again, nervous, expectant.
Ford beckoned to Prosser, who sadly, awkwardly, sat down in the mud.
All except the Hooloovoo were resplendent in their multicolored ceremonial lab coats; the Hooloovoo had been temporarily refracted into a free-standing prism for the occasion.

Only six people in the entire Galaxy understood the principle on which the Galaxy was governed, and they knew that once Zaphod Beeblebrox had announced his intention to run as President it was more or less a fait accompli: he was ideal presidency fodder.
Gasping with horror he scrabbled at his ear for a second or so, but then slowly turned goggle-eyed with wonder.
Ford pressed a large red button at the bottom of the screen and words began to undulate across it.
Desperately he grabbed for the only bit of culture he knew offhand—he hummed the first bar of Beethoven’s “Fifth.”
The Vogon perused them.

By a totally staggering coincidence, that is also the telephone number of an Islington flat where Arthur once went to a very good party and met a very nice girl whom he totally failed to get off with—she went off with a gate-crasher.
underlines.note: uninvited guest. who entered without a ticket

underlines.representative_text: The Vogon raised a surprised eyebrow that effectively obscured his nose and was therefore no bad thing.
His voice was rising to a horrible pitch of impassioned stridency.
But at that moment the guard renewed his grip and continued his original purpose of lugging his prisoners to the airlock.
For a moment his embittered racial soul had been touched, but he thought no—too little too late.
“And shouting, sure,” said Ford, patting the blubbery arm clamped round his neck in friendly condescension, “and he doesn’t even know why he’s doing it!”
The guard grasped them both firmly round the neck, and bowing deferentially toward his captain’s back, hoicked them both protesting out of the bridge.
bellowed the guard.
But if it’s mostly lousy,” he said, slowly giving the words time to reach their mark, “then why do you do it?

Though the planet Earth, the Islington flat and the telephone have all now been demolished, it is comforting to reflect that they are all in some small way commemorated by the fact that twenty-nine seconds later Ford and Arthur were rescued.
Ford leaped in with the coup de grace:
He did this with a small feeble gesture, because he was too asphyxiated to speak.
underlines.note: stranger to death. unable to breathe

underlines.representative_text: He hummed quietly and mused to himself, lightly fingering his notebook of verses.
Deep rumblings of bemusement came from the guard.
The Vogon began to read—a fetid little passage of his own devising.
Many respectable physicists said that they weren’t going to stand for this, partly because it was a debasement of science, but mostly because they didn’t get invited to those sorts of parties.
“Listen,” said Ford, who was still engrossed in the sales brochure, “they make a big thing of the ship’s cybernetics.
“I don’t know,” said Trillian, “but those aliens—they’re on the way up to the bridge with that wretched robot.

Its crew of four were ill at ease knowing that they had been brought together not of their own volition or by simple coincidence, but by some curious perversion of physics—as if relationships between people were susceptible to the same laws that governed the relationships between atoms and molecules.
“I wish you’d stop sulking about that bloody planet,” said Ford.
It was either that or the dole queue again on Monday.”

He sat at it for a while and tried to compose a new entry for the Guide on the subject of Vogons but couldn’t think of anything vitriolic enough so he gave that up too, wrapped a robe round himself and went for a walk to the bridge.
Arthur would not be deterred.
